wow I used to come here a lot as a kid and remembered enjoying the hot dogs so instead of my usual gene n jude's hotdog I decided to come here since its been like 12 years...and it was dissapointed :( the hotdog was small to me and didn't have enough garnishes i got it with everything. The fries were dry and large and not salted and not that warm. The only good thing I can say is the peppers on the hotdog were amazing :) soooo........thats about it.  I'll stick to my greasy fries wrapped up in my hot dog :)

My fiance and I got hot dogs and fries from here today. When asked how he liked it, he said,"I don't know if you can get a better hot dog." I concur.  The fries were excellent.  They're serious about the no ketchup thing.

This is the best Hot Dog in Chicago!   It's not a ritzy ditzy place.  You go in order and eat in your car...and enjoy.  They put mustard, onion, relish and sport peppers and that's it.  The reason this a true chicago hot dog is because it's been around since 1954 and they're  still doing business.  Jimmy's is the best and I have to say Gene's and Jude's is a close second.

The only thing that has changed at Jimmy's since I first went there over 30 years ago, is they have parking. Yay! since I don't live a few blocks away anymore. Yes, this place is close to my heart, I used to walk over when I was a kid and plunk down the loose change I found under the couch cushions to get a real Chicago dog and fries. This place is still so reasonable that I'm sure neighborhood kids are still doing the same. Standing outside of Jimmy's the other day I inhaled, ah yes, same smell. Go in and order up, oh crap husband asks for ketchup, for his fries. The guy points to the sign, "no ketchup, don't even think about it..." I'm hanging my head, and wishing for the moment to be over.  We rustle out and eat in the car, perfection. Same smell, same taste. Wow how can something be that consistent, it hasn't changed.  As Bon Jovi said, you can go home. Yes, my first zip-code was 60651. And I'd bet I heard of Jimmy's before any of the other Yelper's. Hell I know I'm older than most and my first time here I was under 10. I even dated one of the counter guys, yes nothing like free food. Thanks Jimmy's for still being there and making me feel like all these years didn't slip by.

This was stop #3 on our Chicago Hot Dog Tour and by far our least favorite. Yeah, the dog and fries are ok, but they've got nothing on other places. The bun was very soggy. And there was no pickle or celery salt, and for me, those two items are a MUST! The dog was small, even though red hots are supposed to be small. Prices are decent, so at least I didn't feel ripped off...but beware - CASH ONLY! And they have an off duty cop behind the counter, so you can feel safe in that, but kind of sad that they need it. Comes with the territory. And there's no seating, so you'll have to take your food home with you. All in all, an ok experience, but I don't think I'll be returning. There are better places closer to home.

For all of you that get a hard on over Jimmy's, get a room. And when you finally do get that room, spread the grease all over yourself and have some of the most slipperiest of sex ever. Of course, most of that grease will come from the fries, jam packed sticks of turds wrapped around a squashed bun.  Whoopee, you love this place! While I can barf into that complimentary waxed bag after consuming all those fries and a disgracefully prepared Vienna Beef.  On the other hand, it is not totally prepared disgracefully, the dogs do have a snap, the most important aspect of all. You can ask them to bag your fries separately if you don't want a squashed bun, I've done that. Yes, the price for the dog with that amount of fries is unbelievable.  The little Vienna dog goes down in no time and you'll end up spending most of your time eating those fries. If you are driving, you just might pick at the fries until they are finished. I'll eat practically any warm fry that has been cooked properly. Once it starts getting cold, forget about it, I throw them away.  Overall, I might eat the fries and they may be the best to some, but not a big fry person. I'd rather have two dogs or a double dog than all those fries. If your objective is to be filled up cheap, it works, the fries will certainly do it. The depression era days are back, Jimmy's is here to save the day.

this place is guilty of the ultimate condiment crime. i realize that people are going to look at me like i'm batshit crazy if i ask for ketchup at chicago hot dog places. i don't ask anymore (and this place has a sign telling you not to even think about it), but when your other specialty is fries (which are damn good), you need to get on it. no ketchup for fries????!!!!! lame.  this whole chicago "food attitude" thing is getting old. yeah, i like thin crust pizza and ketchup, and if you try to put a pickle near my hot dog i will spit on that shit. get over it. i asked this dude for ranch for the fries, and he gave me crazy face and asked what that was. i said "what am i supposed to dip all these fries in????" he said MUSTARD. gross. overall, fun little place. hot dog was only ok, imo, but fries are worth it. just bring your own ketchup and ranch.

No frills, no muss, no fuss, the perfect formula for a Chicago style hot dog.  The interior of this location is pretty much slab concrete and hot dog making stations.  I made the unfortunate mistake of ordering extra fries with my dogs and came home wielding the world's largest bag of fries, or at least so it seemed.  Fries come with each hot dog, and trust me, one serving is more then enough.  The hot dogs were tasty, the fries a bit too soggy.  The vibe of the place was good, with friendly workers and patrons very excited about their red hots.   Cash only and hurray for the no ketchup clause!

I've always loved Jimmy's... I've been eating here since I was a fetus lol and so has my daughter. The fries are great and its by far besides Jim's Original on maxwell st. The best hot dog/ polish stand in the city... oh yea dont be a dufus and ask for ketchup... you will be laughed at tremendously =)

I have so many childhood memories of eating at Jimmy's Red Hots, perhaps it was because Jimmy's was a family tradition.  My parents often went there in their youth and proceeded to take my brother and I to Jimmy's after a long day of fun in the sun or if we were suddenly craving hot dogs and really, really good (but oh so greasy) french fries.   To me, Jimmy's Red Hots serves the best dogs in town.  Sure, the fries will clog your arteries, but their fresh cut fries are the bomb.  Top is off with a large lemonade and you have a filling, but refreshing meal.  The prices are extremely inexpensive, for hot dogs, fries and a drink, you will be set back about $3.50 and to top it off you are out of there, with order in hand, in less than 10 minutes.  Why so inexpensive, perhaps it's because Jimmy's Red Hots doesn't invest in packaging.  There have been a few instances when I have received my orders in Burger King bags. Definitely, check out Jimmy's Red Hots if you are looking for a good Chicago dog, great fries and don't have time to waste. But a word of advice, don't dare ask for ketchup on your hot dog.  Not only is it a sacrilegious thing to do to a Chicago-style hot dog, there is a sign indicating to never ask for ketchup. To top it off a lot of the order takers are dare I say, big guys, by the way.  Needless to say, to avoid being ridiculed, don't ask for ketchup!  Enjoy!

I remember when I was little we'd come here, but my mom wouldn't tell me where it was.  I just knew it was far from where we lived.  Yesterday my mom wanted a hot dog and we drove past Doug's, but the line was a little longer than she could take (she has a bad knee/arthritis) and when we tried to think of where else we could go she blurted out "Jimmy's!"   They give you a heap of fries and it's cheap.  We were trying to figure out how much money they make, and determined it's A LOT.  A person goes in, and right out they come with a bag of food and a drink or two.  Their turnover was FAST.  My mom went in and in the time I turned to get my newly purchased Weeds Season 4 DVD and put my seatbelt back on, she was getting back in the car.   I've always loved Jimmy's and every now and then when I need some greasy fries and a simple dog, I'll be coming here.  Sometimes I just don't have the patience for Doug's, or the time.

Jimmy's is descent but I really don't see what all the fuss is about. Its just a regular tasting hot dog. If I'm hurting for a hot dog right at the very moment that I happen to drive by Jimmy's than I'll get one but I most certainly would NOT go out of my way to get a dog from them.

OK, so you wanna real Chicago hotdog and not some pretentious yuppie dog that contains ingredients you've never heard of? Good, step right in to a piece of Chicago history. THIS is the place that born and raised Chicagoans go to for the real deal. It's not fancy and you won't be getting any frills, but they do have fries and that's a plus! This is THE text book Chicago dog, not some creative or corporate imitation.

JIMMY'S V. GENE & JUDE'S  My buddy Jeff rates Jimmy's and Gene & Jude's as Chicago's finest dogs.  I had never been to either, so we decided go on a quest to determine #1.  Jimmy's wins in my book for the following reasons:  1) AMAZING Red Hots made to order, with delicious seasoned fries that were fried to crisp perfection (Gene & Judes' fries were a little soggy...my buddy said the potato station might be "rushed" because the line was so long)  2) Absolutely NO wait. We went on a Saturday afternoon: in & out with grub in 45 seconds, no joke (G& J took around 20 minutes). 3) Jimmy's served the dogs in a Burger King bag, which made me laugh. I guess there's a variety of other restaurant bags they rotate. Hippies would say it's "green" because they're reusing. 4) An armed Chicago police officer was working behind the counter, not sure why, but it's always nice to see the force "serving."  5) Jimmy's is located in Chicago (G&J is in River Grove), so the drive isn't as long if you live in the city.  Jimmy's totally rocked my face off and I can't wait to go back. I'll also give Gene & Judes' another shot, I'm sure it's better on weekdays.  Props to Mr. Jeff for taking me on the tour!

Woo hoo. Yelp review #100. I am going to step on some toes here. Jimmy's Red Hots has been in business for about as long as Superdawg [c.v.]. My uncle Willy [c.v.] was the person who first told me about this place back in the late 1960s. He loved its hot dog. But whereas Superdawg went the 'fancy-shmancy' route of selling the sideshow, Jimmy's adhered to the important aspect: The basic commodity. The menu at Jimmy's is _complicated_. I will explain it in detail. Try to memorize this. Here you can purchase =  Hot dog Polish sausage French fries Tamale Got that? I certainly hope so. (And there are also a lot of soda choices.) The hot dog is a size ten. It is cooked well, although it doesn't have a discernible snap to its casing. The onions and relish are chopped and fresh. You can also have hot peppers on your hot dog. (I believe tomatoes are not on the menu here. Then again, ketchup is unavailable for the fries as well.) What provides the major boost to the rating here is Jimmy's french fries. They are hand-cut, the medium size, and are cooked to greasy softness (even the odds and ends). I love them. They are also very, very salty. (YMMV.) There are _two lines_ here. One is at the north end of the business, perpendicular to its parking lot. (The door slams shut loudly.) The other is at the wider southern portion of the property, where you will likely enter if you came here on the bus. Both lines flow north to south; so if you opt for this second line, head for the center. If you persist at chatting on your mobile telephone while in the line, you run a risk of being skipped when it is your turn to order. There are no seats inside here. You can stand at a counter with views of the streets. The prices here have been reverse-calculated to total to easily-purveyed amounts. For example; the $2.27 hot dog and the 92¢ soda will accumulate to $3.50; two hot dogs are $5.00; two hot dogs & a soda are $6.00. A television program (local or national) is not going to send a camera crew here. If you want to see and be seen eating a hot dog, you will go elsewhere. But if you care about the quality of the hot dog, and you don't want to go into debt buying one, you will visit Jimmy's Red Hots. Transit options: The #53 Pulaski bus runs here all the time. The #65 Grand bus runs eastbound from here until 9:30 pm, and until 10:30 pm westbound. You are also two blocks south of the #72 North bus, which operates until 1:15 am every day.

Yum Yum Yum, everyone loves Jimmy's!  If you are in the area or not, you have to stop by to grab a dog and fries.  If you go around lunchtime, be prepared to wait in line, but it's well worth it.  For $2.50, you can have yourself a dog with a generous helping of fresh cut fries.  Okay, so I know the dogs are good, but the fries are another story!  They are nice and soft on the inside and crispy on the outside; the flavor is amazing.  I could eat way too many of these fries if I'm not paying attention.   FYI:  The area is a little....urban, so if you want to go, get over it and just suck it up.  Also, don't ever, ever, ever ask for ketchup here.  They don't have any and they will scold you for asking.  You will find yourself in a room full of people shaking their heads at you in disbelief.  I've heard....so if you like ketchup, prepare yourself and get you own. Must go!

OK,so my review might be biased as this is my old nieghborhood were I actually grew up. And my comment might be outdated as I haven't been in forever.I don't live in the city anymore...haven't in 10 yrs.But after reading these reviews,it sounds like Jimmy's still has that authentic touch. I do hafta say though, this is not the original shack ,the old one burned down many moons ago.But when they rebuilt they did it right,no seats,same menu,same cooking methods. Looks like the next time I'm in town I might hafta swing by Jimmys' for old times sake!!! DJEAT YET?!?

So the neighborhood might be a tad sketchy, but Jimmy's has one thing that I haven't found in any other hot dog in the city.  That one thing is "snap".  Maybe it's the white ceramic pots they're boiled in, but these dogs have the perfect snap when you bite into 'em.  They also serve polish sausages, but the real star is the hot dog.  Their fries are great, too - fresh cut, perfectly salted, moist on the inside, and crisp on the outside. Don't be an idiot like me on my first trip and ask for ketchup or grilled onions.  Only mustard, relish, onions, and sport peppers here.  How I missed that "No Ketchup!" sign behind the counter I still have no idea!

My favorite hot dogs and fries by far! I've been going for 15+ years and is the same as I remember it. I think the prices haven't changed much too. There are two lines there when it's busy so step on down to get served faster. Don't ever order ketchup, sometimes I like ketchup on my fries, but they don't need it here. When I think of Chicago Hot Dogs I think of Jimmy's.

This is definitely the best Hot Dog in town, if you got the guts to try it. Born and bread in LSQ, used to go here all the time when there used to be a Handy Andy around the block ( that's way back young bucks) and I fly in from wherever city I'm in Pensacola, Charlotte, Boston, and have to have my Jimmy's fix. Hot dog w/ everything, the polish is a must, never had the tamale's (why the heck would I order a tamale from a hot dog stand?) superdawg? wiener circle? Demon dogs? Byron's? Jimmy's keeps away the cream puffs, and keeps the best dog for the true Chicagoan's!

I used to go to Jimmy's when I was a kid.  Whenever some New York smart ass thinks they're hot dogs are better then ours I take them to Jimmy's and they change their punk ass minds.   They will give you ketchup packets but they will not put it on the dog.  The fries are soggy potato skins that look like they were violently thrown in with the dog, they're delicious. Service is the Chicago impatient kind.  Be sure you know what you want when you get up front and order fast. This place is great, but you might get robbed a few times on your 50ft trip from the car to the counter and back (carry out only).  Rumor has it that one of the cooks always has a gun in the back of his pants, seriously.   For the foreigner:  Don't walk into Jimmy's with an uppity attitude about the aggressive anti-ketchup policy and expect your whining to be acknowledged. They don't have the patience here. If you want to whine go be one of those ignorant customers that use the N-Word at the Wiener's Circle.  If you want ketchup suck it up and squeeze the packets onto the dog yourself, everyone else does.

I have only been here once and it was pretty good. I am still a fan of Gene and Judes, but these are almost identical. The neighborhood was kinda sketchy and Im not sure if ill go back when Gene and Judes tastes basically the same.

Ok, so no doubt my husband will do a way better review of this place from a chicagoan's viewpoint, but let me give you the viewpoint from someone who moved there later in life.... So, when I moved to Chicago, I was like, what the heck.  What is the psychotic obsession with hot dogs in this town.  I mean, I lived in New York and maybe had like 2 hot dogs from a street cart in times of broke and hungry desperation...So I could not understand this town and their hot dog insanity. Then I had Jimmys.  THE BEST DARN HOT DOGS IN THE WORLD.  Like crack.  The buns are steamed the hot dogs are tasty vienna beef.  The hand cut french fries are beyond.  I'd disagree with the Gene & Judes being better.  Jimmy's fries are better and better location. I'm now a Chicago hot dog convert and on weight watchers...so on my list of absolute to die for indulgences is a Jimmys hot dog and a half - yes I said it - and a half.  And ALL of the darned fries!!! But don't ask for ketchup...just don't.

The hot dogs were pretty good, but the fries could have been better. Being that it is located in the city a double dog here will run you damn near $3.50. This place is comparable to Gene & Judes, but I think Gene & Judes dogs and fries are better. Next on my list of eats from this restaurant is the Polish- I hope there better than their dogs

"Nobody puts ketchup on a hot dog." - Dirty Harry I found that little gem of a quote on the shirts of the employees at Jimmy's.   They have four items at Jimmy's: 1) Hot dogs 2) Polish sausages 3) Fries 4) Tamales You can get relish, onions, mustard, and jalepenos on your hot dog or Polish.  That's it.  No whining.   The employees won't hear it.  They use Vienna beef so you know that dog's gonna snap when you bite into that steamy, warmed bun.  The fries are thick, greasy, and swimming in salt.  Jimmy's is the physical embodiement of a heart attack and boy is it ever good. FYI - The area can be a little "sketchy" at times.  But you don't need to know that you hardcore urban dweller you.

Again, Chris H's description stands as perfect of this institution.    Granted, you can go to a myriad of bootlegged maxwell streets throughout the city at this point.  The spots on canal are still dead on as well, but Jimmy's is like a church of chicago doggery and polishedness.   As far as the 'no ketchup' controversy; transplants need to recognize the importance of a chicago character.  The city protects historic bungalows as condos spring up throughout the city on a single blueprint.  At the same time, joints like hot doug's come up so jagbags can get foie gras on hot dogs made out of deer meat and marvel at french fries cooked in duck fat.   Jimmy's has been and will continue to be the standard for chicago -maxwell street style- hot dogs and polishes (as opposed to the chicago hot dog with celery salt and neon relish).  In the same vein as the pizza boxes from lou malnati's cross out pineapple and chicken as acceptable ingredients, jimmy's flaunts their anti-ketchup stance.   I thank them for this.  Without standard bearers, Chicago could melt into a town of expensive submarine sandwiches (eww) and tin half balconies.
I love Jimmy's.  Cheap, yummy and quick.  Fries are soooo good.

Jimmy's is THE BEST,  authentic and affordable true chicago style hotdog/polish in the Americas. It gets no better then this here folks. The location is a bit ghetto, but nothing drastic. Spacious empty parking, easily accesible from downtown via Grand Ave going N West away from downtown or bus grand/pulaski. Service is very fast and efficient, in and out operation. You can also pick up some cd's and dvd's as you exit.  IF YOU ARE NOT, a native of chicago, then you problaly don't understand the concept of "NO KETCHUP/CATSUP" You feel like you have a constitutional "right" to get ketchup or catsup at your desire! right?.. Wrong.. not in chicago. Especially not in a hardcore real chicago home-town classic like Jimmy's. Respect the sign which states "NO KETCHUP!!"  Don't even think about asking for it, just shut up and keep moving. Trust me.  The main attraction are the fries, they are EXCELLENT, and very generous portions. The hotdogs are very good, but i preffer the polish, all the way - extra peppers. For about 4bucks you get a REAL-DEAL. Especially if you consider you are eating PURE BEEF, No BS.  SO when in chicago make sure to stop in at jimm'ys.. Just remember, NO KETCHUP!!, even if you must have it, respect the local culinary tradition and just enjoy it. Have cash in hand, Not much needed. PLEASE no cell phones.. and be friendly with the guys they work their asses off trying to feed the city. and make us all proud with their works. And.. while you wander around them parts, take DIVISION AVE N to california AVE and find EL BORINQUEN.. try a jibarito.. it will change you forever.

Jimmys jimmys jimmys  o how greasy r your fries? Use to be one of my main stops for a hot dog back in da day. Doesn't taste as good to me ne more.  Could b pickin it up on a sober day.  Their fries are pretty good despite the oil seeping through the bag. Definitely fast service and cheap food. I'll still stop in just  because..... well it's Jimmys.  Although I am a Gene and Jude fan You can not NOT like jimmy's.  haha.

Best Hot dogs around !!Super cheap and their fries are good too !!Ive been coming to this location for years and love that they stay open late and I can be in an out in about 2 minutes with my order .

It's all about the garbage cans filled with cut fries and HUGE tubs of lard! This is not for your hipster vegan friends, but this is real SHYTOWN food. Extra bonus for the no register, all cash transactions that they add up off the top of their head. I feel you ;)

If you've been returning here for 40+ yrs (as I have) then how could you not give it full 5 stars?! a) pure beef dogs in the best sense of the word; b)  I defy you to find another pure beef dog stand THAT'S CHEAPER!; c)  yes, they actually have signs up at the counter that say "don't even THINK of asking for ketchup, and "CELL PHONES = NO SERVICE"; d) lightning fast service--you can time them in seconds. The neighborhood locale here some might characterize as a bit rough; well a couple yrs after we married my wife surprised me with some Jimmy's Red Hots on the kitchen table when I came home one day--I had found me a keeper and that confirmed it (she was not from these parts), and we both ENJOYED! Go here in character--take the Pulaski or Grand Ave CTA bus.

Okay....get over the no ketchup thing. I understand everyone is entitled to their own taste. If you like ketchup on your hot dog, then just don't eat here. Personally ketchup DOES NOT belong on a Chicago style hot dog. Sorry....you can go anywhere in Chicago and ask for "everything" on a hot dog, and it never includes ketchup.  This place has been here for a long time. My parents have memories of going here and family member from out of town, will still make the trip to Jimmys to get their HD and amazing fries whenever they get a chance. Hands down the best fries...period! Hot Dog is exactly how it should be. Steamed warm bun, Vienna hot dog, mustard, relish onion. They wrap it all together which just rubs the taste off on each other and it makes it even more heavenly.  Super Cheap too....no $6 for a flippin Hot Dog...you can actually afford to eat here. It is greasy because of the fries....but how could you expect it not to be. It is feel good food for the tummy. If you are adamant about ketchup, bring some packets from Mc Donalds or something...but quit whining about it already. Plan ahead if it means that much!!! I won't even take a star away for the "beggers" that sometimes get you as you walk in....It's that good.  tamales, in a generic kind of way are good too..... I only like them for nostalgic reasons...not based on actual authentic-ness. But still good.

BEST dog in the city.  I havent been to jimmys in FAR too long but I can still feel the grease on my fingers that soaked thru the paper from the fries.  They are amazing.  Damn, I love me some jimmys.

What i can I say, I must agree with everyone on this one. This is by far one of the best places I have had a dog or a polish sausage. There fries are just as amazing. nothing to hide here and the prices are very cheap. I recommend this place to anybody A few months back I had my friends in from Texas and I told them we had to go to this place. Of course what did they say.... "hot dogs, we could make dogs here." I said true but not this damn good. So we went and what do know  I had each and everyone one of them convinced. Of course my brother was upset that they didn't have ketchup for the dog but I told him that's just Chicago.   Anyways check this place out.

Well,  thanks to Yelp, I checked this place out today.  I am working a construction job nearby, so I tried it for break time at 10:30 am.  Parking was great.  Huge lot with plenty of spaces.  It was very empty, so I  was in & out quickly.  I got 2 dogs with everything.  I knew, thanks to Yelp, about their aversion to ketchup.  I wanted it for my fries.  Doesn't everyone?  They said "we don't have ketchup".    OK, WTF?  So  I  left, I was there for about 2 minutes.  I ate in my truck.  The fries were fucking awesome.  The dog gets buried below them.  Dog was good.  No problems.  But the fries are great.  Coulda used some goddamn ketchup , though.  They give you a shit house of fries with each dog.  i couldn't finish them, which is rare. This ketchup thing is gay.  I was born, raised & still live in Chicago.  If I want ketchup on my goddamn dog, fucking give it to me you fucking douchebags!  Fuck that, I ain't going back.  They could give a fuck, but still, it's stupid.
Places like this is what makes the 'Chicago' dog possible. The place is a lot like Jim's and Express Grill near where it's noisy, steamy and greasy and there's nothing wrong with that.

Yes.... By far the best hot dog in the city.  They make the dog and polish as perfect as it can possibly be.  To the one reviewer, "everything" means exactly what they gave you.  We live in CHICAGO.  The bun was soggy because it is steamed as it should be.  They don't serve ketchup here, which is great.  If any of you think a Chicago style hot dog includes ketchup, then your review is of no value.  Sorry, had to say it.  If you want a REAL Chicago hot dog go to Jimmy's...Oh ya,  a hot dog is not supposed to be healthy, so expect grease.

Ew. Why do you people like this place? I visited Hot Dougs and decided it was so good that I would try some more local hot dog places. EW. Can I say that anymore ? The dog was like it was heated in a microwave. The bun was gross. "EVERYTHING" meant mustard , onions and sport peppers. What? Ew. The fries were beyond greasy. Not even good greasy, just dirty oil greasy.  All the guys that worked there just barked at you, "TWO LINES , MOVE UP" . I won't go back.  I realize if you've gone here while growing up its nostalgic. I just needed to review it honestly based on food and service.

I LOVE this place!! I have been going there since a little girl.  When I came home from college, this was my first stop.  I now live on the opposite side of the city and I drive 30 minutes to get one of these.  When I'm mad at my husband he brings one home.  I can go on and on... I always order a double dog no relish.  The fries are to die for...Oh my gosh!  This is THE place to go to for a hot dog or polish. I've never had the polish but my friends and family love them.  Their hot dogs are never over cooked (lack flavor because they've been soaking in water).   You have go to go by here, you will not regret it!!

Chris H.'s review of Jimmy's is accurate to a T (tee? tea?  Whatever)!!! When I lived in West Logan Square and worked in the burbs, on the way home I used to drive down North Ave. every night and cut down Grand by Pulaski so I could get some Jimmy's.  I have had COUNTLESS discussions with people about ketchup on hot dogs and polishes and people seem to think it's normal for a Chicago hot dog to have ketchup!  These people must have never been to Chicago or are (again) Naperhole transplants from the burbs where food is bland and ketchup (in their world) is Tabasco. Jimmy's does have the "we-don't-have-ketchup-so-don't-ask" sign on the wall where you walk in, and rightly so.  It's very Soup-Nazie-esque like the Seinfeld episode...kind of like how you'll get cursed out by the ladies at the Weiner's Circle on Clark for not being able to order properly! If you carry a Goo-chee or Coach purse, don't go here.  You won't like it; and they won't like you (though they may like what's in your purse, unless there's no cash in it and said purse is all for show like many trendy purse-zilla sad Paris Hilton wannabees do).  But if you want a TRUE Chicago non-"Gold Coast Dogs" hot dog, the trip to Jimmy's is worth it.

Best fucking polish you can find. It's in a little ghetto neighborhood but man is it ever worth the trip. The fries are delicious. I always get an extra order. I don't think I've ever spent more than 10 dollars at Jimmy's. And that's feeding multiple people. And are you looking for the latest movie releases? You can ALWAYS pick up bootleg DVDs in here. It's so freaking sweet. And the "No Ketchup" sign never ceases to amuse. You're in Chicago, folks. Putting ketchup on your dog is practically illegal.

My love :)  My dad has been taking me to Jimmy's since I was little. He has been coming to Jimmy's since he moved here from New York in the 60s'. Yes, the neighborhood is not the best but Jimmy's is a classic. I have and always will get the same thing, plain hot dog with fries and a pepsi, mmmmmm... i just had some a while ago. I love it. Whomever I choose to date down the road must love Jimmy's, period.

once i was introduced to jimmy's, i was hooked. they make a great polish dog and keep the fries moist in its wrapping. i usually order 2 polishes and oftentimes crash the hell out on my couch from the food coma afterwards! the only thing is would like them to have is ketchup. i dunno why they don't keep a stock of the stuff.

I went to the doctor recently for a physical.   Everything checked out except for the fact that I have slightly high cholesterol.  So going to Jimmy's probably wasn't a great idea.  But my mouth sure thanked me. These fries have to be some of THE BEST I've ever had, aside from the duckfat fries at Hot Doug's.  Seriously.  I cannot recall a time in recent memory that such a delicious taste was on my tongue.  They must fry them in crack. The hotdogs are good too, I liked them better than the Polish sausage.  They're not huge but they come with all the trimmings.  This place is also cheap.  We got more food than we could possibly stomach for about $10.   Definitely check this place out if you want to get a feel for a "real" Chicago dog.  Don't let the neighborhood scare you.

Jimmy's is the indisputable home of the greatest Chicago-style hot dog. By extension, Jimmy's produces the best hot dog in the world. My mother's been eating there for fifty years--my birth was celebrated by my grandfather driving out in a blizzard to pick up from Jimmy's. If you or any you know have never been, now is the time. Period. End of discussion.  Let us wax expository upon the entrance: invariably, a homeless person holds the door for you as you sidle into the line. Note the sign to your right: "No ketchup. Don't ask: we don't have any. Don't even think about it!" Kindly nod to the entrepreneur to your left, selling illicit DVDs of movies still in the theatres. Wipe your glasses as you approach the steamy tubs from which the handgun-carrying staff members draw the perfectly cooked Vienna Beef nectar known to all as the "red hot." Call out something other than "with everything," and instantly all eyes burn with fury against you: declining any of the onions, relish, mustard and/or sport peppers is an affront--in my words and not my words alone--'punishable by banishment to the fucking suburbs.' Watch as those angelic, tatooed hands dump freshly lard-fried fries onto the wax paper; the effortless flick of the salt canister; the crispy cacophony as your hot dog is wrapped and deposited into the perfectly congruous United Airlines doggybag. Tip the homeless door-holder on the way out. Repair to a quiet location to enjoy your moment with the divine. Ahhhh. THAT'S a hot dog.

A Chicago institution. Fast service, simple menu, cheap eats, and a good place to score bootleg dvd's. Not every ingredient you've come to expect on a chicago-style dog, but the true vienna taste holds up. Get a tamale, they bring me back to the days of grade school cafeteria lunch. Dog, fries, tamale, small coke=$4 even Current holleywood blockbuster dvd=$10 (3 for $25) ...did somebody say "date night"?

So if you don't live nearby, you're probably going to have to eat this stuff in your car because this is just a walk-in sort of a place. But that doesn't make it any less enjoyable. The hot dogs and fries here are the best in town, without a doubt.
